title.value: WOODS: Benchmarks for Out-of-Distribution Generalization in Time Series
title.justification: Title is evident in the first page of the paper.
title.quote: Title: WOODS: Benchmarks for Out-of-Distribution Generalization in Time Series

extractions.description: The paper introduces WOODS, a benchmark of 11 datasets designed to evaluate Out-of-Distribution (OOD) generalization in time series. The authors focus on domain and subpopulation shifts in diverse data modalities and provide a systematic framework to adapt and evaluate OOD generalization algorithms on these datasets.

type.justification: The paper primarily focuses on introducing a benchmark and evaluating different OOD generalization algorithms on provided datasets through comprehensive experiments, making it empirical.
type.quote: We conduct extensive experiments on the above datasets with ERM and various OOD generalization algorithms.

name.justification: The paper is centered on OOD generalization challenges specifically within the domain of time series data.
name.quote: To shine a light on this gap, we present WOODS: 11 challenging time series benchmarks covering a diverse range of data modalities...

name.justification: The paper considers real-world applications like computational medicine as part of the benchmarks.
name.quote: However, they have been predominantly focused on static computer vision tasks, leaving the field of time series severely underexplored despite being essential to various applications such as computational medicine...

name.justification: The datasets in the benchmark include tasks like forecasting pedestrian counts and electricity consumption.
name.quote: We consider the forecasting task from acceleration and gyroscope measurements...

name.justification: One of the identified tasks involves recognizing emotions from multimodal data.
name.quote: We consider the emotion recognition task. The dataset has 11 time domains, where each domain contains data from a different emotion shifts during conversations.

name.justification: ERM is a critical baseline evaluated across all datasets in the benchmark.
name.quote: Our experiments show a large room for improvement for empirical risk minimization (ERM) and OOD generalization algorithms on our datasets...

is_contributed.justification: ERM is recognized as a standard baseline model in the field of OOD generalization, not a novel contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Our experiments show a large room for improvement for empirical risk minimization (ERM)...

is_executed.justification: ERM models were executed in the benchmark experiments, as apparent from the numerous mentions of their performance.
is_executed.quote: We conduct extensive experiments on the above datasets with ERM and various OOD generalization algorithms.

is_compared.justification: ERM was compared against several OOD generalization algorithms in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: We revise the existing OOD generalization algorithms for time series tasks and evaluate them using our systematic framework.

referenced_paper_title.justification: ERM is rooted in the principles discussed in Vapnik's 'Statistical Learning Theory.'

name.justification: CAP is described in detail and used for the task of sleep stage classification from EEG measurements.
name.quote: We study these machinery-induced distribution shifts with the CAP (Terzano et al., 2001; Goldberger et al., 2000) dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Atlas, rules, and recording techniques for the scoring of cyclic alternating pattern (CAP) in human sleep
referenced_paper_title.justification: The CAP dataset is from the work of Terzano et al., 2001.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We study these machinery-induced distribution shifts with the CAP (Terzano et al., 2001; Goldberger et al., 2000) dataset.

name.justification: SEDFx is described and used to study demographic shifts in sleep stage classification from EEG measurements.
name.quote: We study age demographic shift with the SEDFx (Kemp et al., 2000; Goldberger et al., 2000) dataset (Figure 6).

referenced_paper_title.value: Analysis of a sleep-dependent neuronal feedback loop: the slow-wave microcontinuity of the EEG
referenced_paper_title.justification: The SEDFx dataset is from the work of Kemp et al., 2000.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We study age demographic shift with the SEDFx (Kemp et al., 2000; Goldberger et al., 2000) dataset.

name.justification: PCL dataset is used to study the impact of EEG data gathering procedures.
name.quote: We study these procedural shifts with the PCL (Lee et al., 2019; Cho et al., 2017; Schalk et al., 2004; Jayaram & Barachant, 2018) dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: BCI2000: a general-purpose brain-computer interface (BCI) system.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referred paper outlines the BCI2000 system (Schalk et al., 2004), related to PCL dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We study these procedural shifts with the PCL (Lee et al., 2019; Cho et al., 2017; Schalk et al., 2004; Jayaram & Barachant, 2018) dataset.

name.justification: LSA64 dataset is used for the task of signed word classification from videos.
name.quote: We consider the video classification of signed words in Argentinian Sign Language. The dataset has five source domains, where each domain contains videos of different signers. The goal is to generalize to unseen signers.

referenced_paper_title.value: LSA64: an argentinian sign language dataset.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is based on the work by Ronchetti et al., 2016.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We consider the video classification of signed words in Argentinian Sign Language. The dataset has five source domains, where each domain contains videos of different signers.

name.justification: HHAR dataset is used for human activity recognition across smart devices.
name.quote: We study the ability of models to ignore spurious information from complex signals with the HHAR (Stisen et al., 2015; Dua & Graff, 2017) dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Smart Devices Are Different: Assessing and Mitigating Mobile Sensing Heterogeneities for Activity Recognition.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is from Stisen et al., 2015, focusing on mobile sensing heterogeneities.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We study the ability of models to ignore spurious information from complex signals with the HHAR (Stisen et al., 2015; Dua & Graff, 2017) dataset.

name.justification: PedCount dataset is used for forecasting pedestrian crossings.
name.quote: We study the impact of those trend shifts with the PedCount (City of Melbourne, 2017; Godahewa et al., 2021) dataset (Figure 10).

referenced_paper_title.quote: We study the impact of those trend shifts with the PedCount (City of Melbourne, 2017; Godahewa et al., 2021) dataset.

name.justification: AusElec dataset is used for forecasting electricity consumption.
name.quote: We consider the electricity consumption forecasting task. The dataset has 13 time domains, where each domain contains data from different months and holidays.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset was provided by Hyndman & Athanasopoulos, 2018.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We consider the electricity consumption forecasting task. The dataset has 13 time domains, where each domain contains data from different months and holidays.

name.justification: IEMOCAP dataset is used for emotion recognition tasks over conversations.
name.quote: We consider the emotion recognition task. The dataset has 11 time domains, where each domain contains data from a different emotion shifts during conversations.

referenced_paper_title.value: IEMOCAP: Interactive Emotional Dyadic Motion Capture Database.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referred work by Bulut et al., 2008, outlines the IEMOCAP dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We consider the emotion recognition task. The dataset has 11 time domains, where each domain contains data from a different emotion shifts during conversations.

name.justification: PyTorchVideo is mentioned as a library used for video processing within the dataset preprpcoessing steps.
name.quote: We use PyTorchVideo (Fan et al., 2021) to uniformly sample 20 frames from each video in a sequence for prediction.

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorchVideo: A deep learning library for video understanding.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The visuals reference paper is by Fan et al 2021.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We use PyTorchVideo (Fan et al., 2021) to uniformly sample 20 frames from each video in a sequence for prediction.
